content.content: twitter.com    Aave @AaveAave  1/ Calling all GHOsts 👻   We have created an ARC for a new decentralized, collateral-backed stablecoin, native to the Aave ecosystem, known as GHO.  Read more below and discuss your thoughts for the snapshot (coming soon)!👇  governance.aave.com/t/introducing-…   2:50 PM - 7 Jul 2022           2K                560            This is something that I been saying it will happen since past year, take a look to this old post that I did, and read the responses that I got. Again, in my eyes, Maker should do everything on their own.  staking services (Lido) Money markets (AAVE) Derivatives Dex (dydx) Fixed Yield (Yield) Swaps  everything. Fixing our work in “Dai as a universal currency” does not make much sense. Crypto is not collab. Crypto is adversarial.

image1170×1124 179 KB  We should expect stablecoins launches to become more frequent, no one knows how long the crypto winter will last so it makes sense, stablecoins will continue to grow in the bear market. DAI is battle tested, has weathered multiple downturns without loosing its peg, its market position is strong but this type of threats should be taken seriously. I see GHO’s competitive advantage being that customers benefit from their asset collateral continuing to earn yield as opposed to Maker Vaults where collateral remains uninvested. The demand for this type of setup continues to grow, users are realizing that there are potential yield opportunities to be earn from the locked collateral, and in the current setup no one benefits from idle ETH, WBTC, etc.
This could be the beginning of protocols creating their own collateralized stablecoins?
Could someone explain why this would be a threat to DAI rather than another stablecoin to pool alongside USDC etc? Is it because it has a similar collateralization method?

Since I saw Justin Sun’s move, I assumed that other protocols, and even blockchain networks creating their own. StablecoinSummer e empzado a leer por alli, as you say crypto is not collaboration, crypto is as long as you serve me you will be my ally and if not I will make you competition. We lived it with Curve dropping our importance in 3Poool and now Aave with this move.

image1513×119 17.3 KB  We are talking about the second-largest protocol by TLV and importance after Maker. They are already present in a native way in many channels, which we are not for now. They have a great competitive advantage.

MarianoDP:  Again, in my eyes, Maker should do everything on their own.  staking services (Lido) Money markets (AAVE) Derivatives Dex (dydx) Fixed Yield (Yield) Swaps  everything.   Okay… but currently a lot of governance power here seems to want to slash budgets and offload talent, so HOW?
Instead of holding DAI they would hold GHO…
Why is it mutually exclusive? You can adjust resources by priority. Like extra swag vs improving the protocol
AAVE is a real competitor, they have wider reach and more users than MKR
AAVE has stolen a march on Maker hopefully it will give Maker a new sense of urgency

I do not believe this is an accurate representation Rune’s vision. As I understand  it, his position is: First, to clarify and reduce the core and complexity of Maker such that it has minimal real world entanglements and tail risk. Almost all agree with reducing the core to “Rai +” Second, there is a massive investment in new structures to expand existing business lines and develop new ones. This would likely be in excess of current budgets. In a way, the proposal establishes a clear vision and clarifies the boundaries of where protocol aspects lie. From there, resources are redistributed to achieve this new vision and the associated objectives. Contributors to these new structures would also have additional incentives tied to their personal performance, making the structure more charitable and generous to individual contributors and core units. With the “MetaDAO” portion there seems to be division on the extent to which Maker should support these associated businesses and capital buffers. In all reality, Maker would need to be seeding the initial structures, as they have particular affordances (requirements) best met by Maker where the protocol has the greatest potential gains and upside (as opposed to a third party). Once they have been proven out, having other ecosystem players supporting and developing businesses is more feasible.
I hope they will be getting all the banking licenses together. This will very likely attract regs in the game.
MadShills:  Almost all agree with reducing the core to “Rai +”   Don’t want to derail this thread but I don’t think it’s appropriate to say “almost everyone agrees with me”.

My opinion is, we should take a “wait and see” approach to GHO stablecoin, while continuing to build on our existing network effects and DAI + vault utility; striving to make Maker and DAI the best value prop for stablecoin holders and collateralized borrowers. If Aave begins to take an anticompetitive stance (eg. materially disadvantaging DAI via parameter changes such as raising reserve factor or purposefully making DAI less usable within the Aave money markets), we may be forced to launch our own competing liquidity protocol to ensure DAI can continue to access the market for longer tail collateralized lending on an equal basis. I think this would reduce Maker’s focus (even if we found an incentive compatible way to spin the new liquidity protocol out into a metadao) so I would prefer to avoid this. I have similar concerns about the forthcoming Compound v3 protocol, which as described features a single borrowable asset per market. Will DAI be available to borrow on Compound v3? I’m hoping we can maintain collaborative relationships with other defi protocols over the long term, but we should also be prepared for a war of attrition if other protocols force the issue.

Hey guys, Emilio here I understand the concerns expressed in this thread. As an OG Aave community member and developer, main architect of GHO and collaborator through both individual contribution and BGD labs, i would personally oppose any anti competitive stance towards other stablecoins, especially DAI which aligns with my ideals of decentralization and has been an inspiration for me from a technical and organizational perspective. I cant talk for the whole Aave community of course but i believe GHO can grow alongside DAI and other stablecoins and help bringing true decentralization and censorship resistance to stable assets, while maintaining the position of Aave as the protocol to use to borrow any stablecoin, not only GHO.

It’s been a while since I posted here so quick prez : I’m marc Head of dev rel @ aave Companies. At this point, Aave & Maker has experienced real synergies for years in DeFi. We worked together, we know each other, liquidity protocols such as Aave helped DeFi grow from a sub B$ market to what we have now, offered DAI holders new pathways of liquidity and yield. As emilio pointed out: there’s absolutely no point for Aave to take a “GHO-maximalist” approach for the aave market stablecoins, other actors in defi seem to aim for that and it’s up to them. there’s according to governance 3 new stablecoins joining Aave versions on several networks, it would be a bit weird to do it if the “big plan” was to compete (note: we’re defi too, big plans are decided in governance forums just like you guys.). My personal opinion backed by market data is that synergies are the best-self interest strategy for DeFi protocols to increase overall ecosystem stability, liquidity, attractivity, and resilience. I think our previous inter-protocol cooperation with the D3M is a good example of this, more liquidity for Aave, better rates for users more revenue for Maker. We think to put this in simple words that GHO helps DAI and DAI helps GHO. GHO being a collateralized-based asset, it is reinforced and reinforces other decentralized stablecoins. a simple example, if GHO is over peg, minting DAI to short it (a new PSM?) helps it to restore peg and provide maker users with opportunities. The same applies both ways. GHO and DAI together are alongside USDC on the centralized part of things a perfect match to always have strong ways to balance a stableswap pool. That means we can expect more liquidity, volume and fees overall. With GHO, Aave wins, but Maker also wins and so curve, convex & other DeFI protocols. In short, DeFi wins and users win. Let’s work together.

AAVE is a DeFi Marketplace expanding into USD stablecoin market which means we would be competing for the same market. We can grow together but ultimately if we were to expand into DeFi marketplace AAVE would not be happy… Makes sense that AAVE would push for GHO as the native onchain/app stablecoin reducing DAI demand…
Thanks for your comments @The3D and @marczeller. I agree that there is definitely potential for mutual benefit.

Thank you @The3D and @marczeller for your posts. In any case, the same elements that both bring up as motivators for continuous collaboration between AAVE and MAKER are the elements that Maker can use to develop a Money Market like AAVE’s. Regardless of the levels of aggressiveness that may exist between the two protocols, at the end of the day there will always be a tendency to favor your product and community, and that’s not bad, that’s how it has to be. Perhaps my position is quite radical, but I still consider and defend that Maker has to have the entire line of products mentioned in the original Post and we will also post to other forums that we only copy the model for continuous collaboration  I’d rather be a Warrior in a Garden than a Gardener in a war.

marczeller:  a new PSM?   We would be ill advised to make a PSM for 1) a coin with no real-time peg reinforcement mechanism, that’s 2) coming after this knife in the back, and 3) isn’t redeemable for money. What would stop you from infinite minting and draining billions from us? Seriously, best of luck but no thank you

Hey all, Stani here (Founder of Aave and MakerDAO fan). Aave Community had long history for working together from listing DAI into the Aave Protocol and also taking DAI into cross-chain yield markets to the invention of D3M (which I proposed to the MakerDAO community as a strategic collaboration between Aave and Maker Community). I am personally dedicated (and I see same takes within the overall Aave Community) on continuing the collaboration between Aave and MakerDAO communities. Similar to the D3M module that I proposed back in 2021, we are always excited to find new innovation to support the growth for both DAI and GHO. I will also not support any anti-competitive measures on Aave governance against DAI and rather see more growth for DAI across all the Aave markets. Excited also to jam with the Maker community on ideas to empower both of the communities

MarianoDP:  Maker should do everything on their own.   I will note that this attitude tends to be cyclical. Real world companies will fluctuate between “we need to do everything, so we can protect our supply chain and keep all the yield for ourselves” and “we need to run lean, focus on our core competencies, outcompete on that and outsource everything else”. Maker has a very strict view on governance that makes it unsuited for a lot of products. I doubt we will have success by trying to do everything.

Hello Aave folks, appreciate these posts. I agree there can be positive-sum synergies between DAI and GHO. This idea of backing GHO with a DAI psm sounds great as it can ensure peg stability for you guys from a fellow decentralized coin. Will this exist as a separate facilitator outside of the Aave V3 market or will you be maintaining the peg upside via the stable-stable emode mostly?

hexonaut:  This idea of backing GHO with a DAI psm sounds great as it can ensure peg stability for you guys from a fellow decentralized coin.   Bro why don’t we let GHO get some traction first,  get purchase, and then don’t lose it, before we start talking PSM, eh?

MarianoDP:  Again, in my eyes, Maker should do everything on their own.  staking services (Lido) Money markets (AAVE) Derivatives Dex (dydx) Fixed Yield (Yield) Swaps  everything. Fixing our work in “Dai as a universal currency” does not make much sense.   Totally agree, smaller teams manage to deliver with significantly less budget, we are going in circles in many cases. We should keep in mind we are still the largest decentralized stable coin, and RWA is currently making great strides. We should focus on what we are good at, even if you can draw synergy effecte with GHO, we should not rest.
for sure, i think until GHO demonstrates it can work at scale, talking about any protocol level peg stability mechanism which involves GHO is premature.

Well like all stablecoins in a bear market you have to back it with other larger cap stablecoins or you lose the peg. It would be nice to cement this relationship with you guys choosing your fellow decentralized stablecoin over centralized alternatives so we can grow together.
That’s a legitimate view @MarianoDP. Wouldn’t change my view in any case, i’d still love to work with Maker
Not weird at all - its actually quite important point, there is lot of work to do towards decentralization of stablecoins for the whole space and always excited to collaborate and innovate together.
Aave has a crucial head start, it has already been deployed in a lot of blockchains. He’s going to be a tough competitor.
those are rookie numbers, we’re at like 80+% now

monet-supply:  My opinion is, we should take a “wait and see” approach to GHO stablecoin, while continuing to build on our existing network effects and DAI + vault utility; striving to make Maker and DAI the best value prop for stablecoin holders and collateralized borrowers.   +1 to this. The GHO stablecoin may or may not change the landscape in the long term for Maker - it’s far too early to tell. In the meantime, let’s build DAI to be the best and most integrated stablecoin possible. Our Aave integration is important for Maker and there’s no reason at this stage to sound the alarm and burn bridges (@MarianoDP’s proposal that Maker should be building out its own verticals is really interesting, though, and I think that should be considered on its own merits…)

There are two things to think about here Looking at it directly, is GHO a direct attack on DAI and the Maker protocol to lose power in the market or is it simply a payment alternative to increase decentralization in the safest stablecoins? Let’s remember the monopoly that USDC has (I don’t like the exposure of DAI to it) BUSD with Binance and USDT (no comment) if we increase more the exposure of decentralized currencies similar to DAI it would not be a long-term benefit to increase the liquid to these coins? I support the simple fact that important representatives of AAVE highlighted to clarify some things, what I would not approve of is that it is just words and there is no contract or legal public agreement And the second I get it from the article posted on the forum It is a parameter that I understand serves to increase the exposure of GHO in the protocol seems very good to me I quote verbatim: A discount model for GHO “The initial implementation of GHO includes a discount strategy mechanism. The initial discount strategy allows Security Module participants (stkAAVE holders) to access a discount on the GHO loan rate. In the first implementation, the The strategy will establish a certain amount of discounted GHO per stkAAVE supplied, and a discount in interest rates that can vary from 0% (no discount) to 100% (full discount)” This measure, understanding that it is to feed the liquidity of GHO and that it will be subject to a change by the DAO participants, but despite seeming good to me, if it becomes permanent, would it not lower the exposure of DAI in AAVE? If the participants of the DAO want to have it forever, wouldn’t that be a risk model? For my conclusion, I like knowing that we all have the same vision of decentralization I see the comments in both forums and we all love anticompetitiveness, also I love that decentralized stablecoins take a much more important role than centralized ones. If everything in GHO turns out excellent, could you think of a collateral proposal GHO - DAI? Or lower the exposure in a future of USDC having an agreement with AAVE and GHO? It would be lovely, of course speaking if everything turns out excellent

Thank you so much for engaging with the community. While I believe there might be some parts that come in conflict, do agree that there will be also many parts that can be collaborated on. Considering AAVE also having been working on working with institutions, is the team also planning to onboard more Real world assets as well?

I personally believe that real world assets will be part of the larger DeFi ecosystem at some point and its a definitely subject where Aave and Maker can collaborate - I would be happy to participate on brainstorming

Yall are shocked that a loan platform is deciding to expand its feature into a stablecoin offering? What shocks me is that people think MakerDAOs main product is stablecoin. DAI is a feature of its main offering and thats loans. Also to put it bluntly, MakerDAO isn’t even interested in working with other protocols already let alone onboarding native on chain assets. Lets not lie outright, the time for that comes with governance proposals. Cheers and enjoy yalls weekend. Allah protect Nikolai. Adios.
Snippet from today’s Bankless newsletter  Screenshot_20220709-104416_Outlook1080×1968 177 KB
Is Aave truly Decentralized?

It is the logical thing to do. There are essentially 2 businesses in DeFi right now. DEXes and lending. For a collateralized lending protocol, having your own stablecoin makes sense. It is an additional revenue stream with very low costs. I would not be surprised if Compound launches its own stablecoin too.

It is logical, so we need to continue to innovate or have a higher interest rate (i.e. DSR) than competitors. Sustainable investment yields are going to be increasingly important. Today, there is also non-custodial money transfers, which is still up for grabs, and NFT

I am not a big fan of the DSR model as it only rewards Dai holders that lock up their crypto. I think interest protocol has the right idea by allowing the stablecoin token itself to  slowly accumulate value.
You can tokenize the position IE chai.
folks who are willing to lock up their DAI for a fixed term are making a loan to Maker and arguably should be paid for this
Are DSR funds eligible for ALM investment or are they kept fully liquid?
Fully liquid. Also there is no lockup.
Thats what I thought, thanks!
This makes sense to me, wouldn’t AAVE want to avoid ending up in our situation, being so exposed to USDC? For DeFi, the more stablecoins the more stable each coin can be, right?

Another point of evidence for your argument @MarianoDP - we can now add Curve to the heap of other protocols (Aave, Interest Protocol) planning on launching a stablecoin:    The Block    Curve Finance founder implies a stablecoin is on its way Curve Finance may be the latest DeFi project joining the race to ship a decentralized stablecoin.
The new wave of stablecoins innovation has arrived, now all protocols want to create their own vision of a decentralized currency. OMG

I’m with the “wait and see” group. So, they intend on using DAI’s minting method, almost 1 to 1; but on the other hand, do they serve the same markets? In terms of DeFi adoption, yeah probably. But at the token generation level, DAI is typically minted by large or institutional investors. GHO will likely be more free-reign, with smaller holders collateralizing assets to mint it. Even with over-collateralization, they’ll be taking on a massive chunk of smaller, riskier loans. I have no clue what that adds to their overhead costs, or if sheer volume would make up the difference, but it feels like they might be over-extending.
alec:  Even with over-collateralization, they’ll be taking on a massive chunk of smaller, riskier loans.   What would be the added risk if its over-collateralized?

TRUEMAKER:  What would be the added risk if its over-collateralized?   I worded that poorly. It’s not necessarily the small loans that add risk, but the volume of them. I could definitely be misunderstanding the technicals, but I imagine each of these small loans adds to the maintenance overhead. More or less, the risk comes in how efficient/profitable the system is without the dust limit.
